project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization under Planning Code Sections 303 and 724.52 to establish a foreign language enrichment program for children. The proposal is to convert a vacant retail use (formerly a women's clothing store) to a personal service use for a language enrichment program (dba Language at Play) offering classes in French, Mandarin and Spanish to children ranging in age from 1 to 10 years, as well as a retail sales component for its language program products. The proposed project will occupy the ground floor (approximately 2,000 square feet) of a two-story building.
action: proposed for continuance to november 15, 2007. continued as proposed
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization to operate a business under this application between the hours of 2 AM and 6 AM. Specifically, the project proposal is to extend the hours of operation of the subject business (dba Broadway Express Pizza Restaurant ) to 3:00 AM. No construction is proposed under this application.
action: proposed for continuance to november 15, 2007. continued as proposed
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2006.02.23.5225, proposing construction of a third-story horizontal and vertical addition to a two story dwelling
action: proposed for continuance to december 13, 2007. continued as proposed
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: The proposed project would include the demolition of the existing one-story, 20- to 26-foot-tall, approximately 8,226-square-foot(sf) industrial building, constructed in 1908, and the construction of a four-story over basement, approximately 43-foot-tall building. The proposed, approximately 32,300 gross-square-foot(gsf) building would include ten residential units on the second through fourth floors over approximately 7,100 sf of Production, Distribution, & Repair (PDR)/Business Service use on the ground and basement levels. The proposed basement level would contain a ten-space residential parking garage (about 5,600 sf) with ingress and egress from Shotwell Street. The proposed project would result in an approximately 24,000 gsf net increase in uses on the project site. The approximately 8,227-sf project site. The proposed project would require Conditional Use authorization for the construction of residential dwellings in an M-1 zoning district pursuant to Section 215 of the San Francisco Planning Code (Planning Code); a Variance to provide less than the required number of parking spaces (Section 151); and an allowable exception for corner lots to satisfy rear yard requirements on the second floor pursuant to Planning Code Section 134(e)2).
type_district_descr_2: mission alcohol beverage special use district
action: proposed for continuance to january 17, 2008. continued as proposed
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Staff Initiated Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application number 2006.02.08.4114. The proposal is to construct a new mixed-use building on a lot currently containing a 22-space private surface parking lot. The proposed structure would contain 8 dwelling units with commercial space and 8 off-street parking spaces on the ground floor. The applicant requests that the Planning Commission remove the springing condition requiring community impact fees and BMR units that was previously imposed on the project.
preliminary_recommendation: take discretionary review and remove the springing condition
action: proposed for indefinite continuance. continued as proposed
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Amendments relating to Planning Code Sections 781.8 [Board File No. 07-1217] - Ordinance introduced by Supervisor Ammiano amending Planning Code Section 781.8 to allow relocation of existing Liquor Establishment in the Mission Alcoholic Beverage Special Use Subdistrict to another location within the same Mission Alcoholic Beverage Special Use Subdistrict; and making findings.
action: supervisor amiano is no longer pursuing this legislation

project_descr: Consideration to approve, disapprove, or approve with modifications the landmark designation of the Noe Valley Branch Library under Article 10 of the Planning Code.
ayes: alexander, olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization to establish a small self-service restaurant (d.b.a. Honeydoo  Frozen Yogurt) of approximately 800 square feet within the existing ground-floor retail space.
speakers: jeremy paul, keith wilson, jim schein, chuck thomas, marc bruno, nan roth, mary lipian, june osterberg, katherine petrin, marsha garland, lynn jefferson, santino derose, alexandria kinkel, kong wu

speaker_statements.speaker: jeremy paul
lines: says many supporters missed the hearing due to late notice
submits letters and signatures from nearby supporters
argues grant avenue lacks pedestrian-oriented uses; this corner is well-suited
clarifies product is chilled yogurt, not frozen yogurt
states historic portions will not be altered and any changes will fit the facade design

speaker_statements.speaker: keith wilson
lines: calls it a perfect business for the location, attracting tourists seeking entertainment and restaurants

speaker_statements.speaker: tony gantner
lines: supports the application, saying it will bring a diverse crowd to the commercial area

speaker_statements.speaker: jim schein
lines: supports giving applicants the opportunity to try to succeed

speaker_statements.speaker: chuck thomas
lines: supports the application for the welfare of the community and hopes the decision isn’t unilateral

speaker_statements.speaker: marc bruno
lines: says a family yogurt business would be an anti-bar, anti-alcohol alternative to uses the neighborhood doesn’t want

speaker_statements.speaker: nan roth
lines: urges policies that protect neighborhood-serving businesses to maintain quality of life
opposes converting the site to another food-and-beverage use

speaker_statements.speaker: mary lipian
speaker_statements.descr: co-chair, planning committee for telegraph hill dwellers
lines: urges adopting staff’s recommendation to disapprove due to loss of retail service sites and the need for balance
says there is no ceqa review for the proposed changes and they haven’t been shared with the neighborhood

speaker_statements.speaker: june osterberg
lines: asks for help restoring variety, not just eating and drinking places

speaker_statements.speaker: katherine petrin
speaker_statements.descr: president, north beach & telegraph hill dwellers (member)
lines: notes conditional use runs with the property, not the business
asks the commission to support planning staff’s findings

speaker_statements.speaker: marsha garland
lines: says it’s time to redefine what is neighborhood-serving and appropriate for ground-floor commercial
notes high rents and lengthy processes economically impact small businesses

speaker_statements.speaker: lynn jefferson
lines: supports the application, saying it would add variety and increase pedestrian traffic

speaker_statements.speaker: santino derose
speaker_statements.descr: owner, pgb llc & crown fortune properties inc.
lines: supports the application but asks for conditions to bar a kitchen and alcohol sales to prevent future restaurant use
says the facade will not be altered and historic character will be preserved

speaker_statements.speaker: alexandria kinkel
lines: concerned about facade alterations shown on the drawings
says interior changes would be substantial and hard to reverse for another tenant

speaker_statements.speaker: kong wu
lines: asks for approval to give him the opportunity to work

ayes: alexander, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, sugaya

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization pursuant to Planning Code Sections 161(j) and 303 for the reduction of off-street parking spaces for proposed dwelling units and for existing dwelling units, to allow construction of a 2-unit mixed-use building
speakers: marc tetrault, marc lindsell, andy thornley, terrie, ellen, donna roberts, gordon thrupp, margaret thrupp, michael smith

speaker_statements.speaker: marc tetrault
lines: submitted an october memo outlining the project’s historical and architectural context
notes the planning code does not require off-street parking for commercial uses in this district and requires one space per dwelling unit
argues requiring off-street parking would severely compromise the commercial space
states street parking is generally abundant nearby and the site sits on a primary transit line with multiple modes

speaker_statements.speaker: andy thornley
lines: supports the project for adding housing and supporting car-free tenants

speaker_statements.speaker: marc lindsell
lines: supports bringing housing instead of leaving an empty lot

speaker_statements.speaker: terrie
lines: objects to a palm tree due to the cortland merchants’ forestation plan
wants windows modified to match existing clear-pane character
opposes no-parking design, noting many buildings on the block have driveways

speaker_statements.speaker: ellen
lines: questions the claim that street parking is abundant and that transit is so amenable that cars can be eliminated

speaker_statements.speaker: donna roberts
lines: opposes the project for removing street parking
calls for an independent parking survey rather than one from the architect

speaker_statements.speaker: gordon thrupp
lines: says the scale is inconsistent with the cortland corridor’s character and impacts open space, air, and light
requests lowering the building by 4% of proposed height and reducing ground-floor commercial height by 1.5 feet

speaker_statements.speaker: margaret thrupp
lines: concerned construction vibration could damage their walls
asks for a condition ensuring the project’s window does not sit above their window sill

speaker_statements.speaker: michael smith
lines: stresses the importance of continuous ground-floor commercial without garage entrances that raise safety concerns for families
opposes a palm tree due to the cortland avenue forestation plan and preference for a consistent canopy

amendments: continue working with staff on design and materials
ayes: alexander, olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization under Sections 186.1(e), 712.45, and 303 of the Planning Code to allow the transfer of ABC License Type 21 from 1600 Lombard Street (previously Goldmine Liquors) to 1926 Lombard Street (d.b.a. Luigi's Delicatessen). The proposal is to add off-sale liquor sales to an existing grocery store (with accessory deli) for the sale of beer, wine, and distilled spirits. The proposal will not involve an expansion of the existing building envelope.
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Request for a Section 309 Determination of Compliance and Request for Exceptions. The proposed project is to construct a 17 story, approximately 205 foot tall (including mechanical penthouses) new mixed-use building at the existing vacant lot, containing approximately 260 dwelling units, approximately 3,000 square feet of ground level commercial space, and a garage with a capacity of up to 113 parking spaces (98 residential spaces and 15 commercial spaces). The project requires separation of towers, rear yard, comfort-level wind, parking, and bulk exceptions pursuant to Section 309(a).
speakers: andrew junius, john perkins jr., david matchett, dawn moore, philip oliver, elizabeth boardman, kristin barnard, michael burnside, pete russell, stephen matchett, bruce folson, paul minault, carol maxwell, [no name stated], steve, daniel fratton, sue hestor, alex, [no name stated], andrew

speaker_statements.speaker: andrew junius
lines: says the project meets the commission’s goals for a downtown project
includes 31 below-market-rate units, less than 1:1 on-site parking, family housing, close to transit, and dense urban infill
states the sponsor is committed and the project fully complies with the downtown plan

speaker_statements.speaker: john perkins jr.
lines: aims for leed certification; extensive experience with high-rises and leed projects
presents a strong urban design with an l-shaped floor plate
materials include clear glass and metal; massing steps down toward mission street
balconies provide angular solar shading, rain protection, and enable owner window washing
developers are conscientious about design; supports leed target and on-site affordable housing

speaker_statements.speaker: david matchett
speaker_statements.descr: chair, san francisco friends meeting (quakers), 65 ninth street
lines: supports housing/retail in principle but has traffic, safety, and noise concerns
says notification and outreach were inadequate until four weeks ago; recent suggestions are not adequate
driveway is designed next to their front door; urges moving garage access to laski street
questions whether units will be primary residences or corporate use
requests time to keep working through concerns; says green standards of original buildings not incorporated

speaker_statements.speaker: dawn moore
lines: garage next to their worship space will create daily, constant noise; calls it an unfair burden

speaker_statements.speaker: philip oliver
lines: parking entrance a few feet from the silent worship room is untenable
calls the project good but asks for time to find agreeable solutions

speaker_statements.speaker: elizabeth boardman
lines: concerned about ninth street garage entrance noise and safety with traffic off the highway

speaker_statements.speaker: kristin barnard
lines: urges withholding approval to continue talks, particularly to shift garage activity to laski street

speaker_statements.speaker: michael burnside
lines: says sponsor did not engage the neighborhood; silence is essential to their worship

speaker_statements.speaker: pete russell
lines: concerned the project aims for leed gold but current proposal does not meet that standard
approval now is premature; asks time to address garage, traffic, safety, and accountability

speaker_statements.speaker: stephen matchett
lines: says many in the area want the garage entry moved to laski street due to noise, traffic, and safety

speaker_statements.speaker: bruce folsom
lines: notes their worship is based on silence and nonviolent solutions developed through time and dialogue; they need that time

speaker_statements.speaker: paul minault
lines: requests a continuance to work creatively with the sponsor
recommends garage entrance on laski street; says obstacles (like left-turn issues) are overstated

speaker_statements.speaker: carol maxwell
lines: concerned about traffic, children’s safety, and accountability since the sponsor won’t be the ultimate owner
says proposed mitigations are insufficient

speaker_statements.speaker: no name
lines: emphasizes the importance of silence to their group
notes ninth street is a major, fast northbound artery at all hours; asks for time to reach resolution

speaker_statements.speaker: steve
lines: argues using laski street for garage access is a neighborhood responsibility that would help clean up the area

speaker_statements.speaker: daniel fratton
lines: rebuts claims of inadequate notice: posters, mailers, and published notices were sent as required
says a july letter and follow-up call to friends were declined; neighbors had a prior settlement with a previous developer ('skif') for $155k
in october, friends sought information but delayed talks until they retained an attorney
offers facade changes and $45k to soundproof the meeting house to avoid disturbance

speaker_statements.speaker: sue hestor
lines: notes friends meeting has raised noise/traffic concerns since 2001 for projects in the area
says ninth street traffic is fast and a garage next to a church with disabled people and children is unsafe

speaker_statements.speaker: alex
lines: cites 40 years’ experience and hundreds of infill projects; award-winning work
believes notice/time for objectors has been sufficient; offered soundproofing to address needs
traffic studies have been submitted; says laski street access is difficult
calls the project excellent, providing housing with 31 affordable units

speaker_statements.speaker: no name
lines: concerned the project will impact silent worship and safety with vehicle traffic
states the project is not ready for approval

speaker_statements.speaker: andrew
lines: says smart growth is central to their developments to add community value
the project addresses city concerns by providing affordable housing and retail near major transit

first_action: to approve with conditions that are amended
first_amendments: per project's sponsor's offer, pay $45,000 to the Friends Meeting to use their building in any way they chooes but mainly for ambient noise
to close the 9th street gate all day on sundays from 6a.m. to 6p.m. and on tuesday to leave it open with an attendant from 5:30 - 10p.m.
action: without public hearing closed, continued to december 13, 2007
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization to allow additional square footage above the base FAR of 6.0 to 1 for dwelling units that will be affordable for a minimum of 20 years to households whose incomes are within 150 percent of the median income, for the project described in item above.
speakers: andrew junius, john perkins jr., david matchett, dawn moore, philip oliver, elizabeth boardman, kristin barnard, michael burnside, pete russell, stephen matchett, bruce folson, paul minault, carol maxwell, [no name stated], steve, daniel fratton, sue hestor, alex, [no name stated], andrew
action: with public hearing closed, continued to december 13, 2007
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore

project_descr: Request for usable open space dimension and dwelling unit exposure variances in connection with the mixed-used project described in item above. The request for variances will be considered by the Zoning Administrator.
speakers: andrew junius, john perkins jr., david matchett, dawn moore, philip oliver, elizabeth boardman, kristin barnard, michael burnside, pete russell, stephen matchett, bruce folson, paul minault, carol maxwell, [no name stated], steve, daniel fratton, sue hestor, alex, [no name stated], andrew
action: zoning administrator closed public hearing and continued this item to december 13, 2007

project_descr: Request for a Conditional Use Authorization, pursuant to Planning Code Sections 703.3, 703.4, and 712.44, to allow a formula retail small self-service restaurant (d.b.a. Subway)
speakers: peter sangha, maria cisneros, glenda gutierrez, cristy johnston, silvia johnson

speaker_statements.speaker: peter sangha
lines: notes the site has been vacant for about a year and needs improvement
says a 20-year lease is signed but contingent on approval
states subway provides healthy, affordable food choices
plans to invest about $200,000 for new windows, doors, and full interior/exterior renovations
will work with the excelsior action group to hire local residents; aims for seven full-time employees
says there is no subway along mission and hopes this becomes a pathway for others to enter the business

speaker_statements.speaker: maria cisneros
lines: supports the application because the building has been vacant a long time
says subway is healthy and affordable and would enhance the building

speaker_statements.speaker: glenda gutierrez
lines: says many businesses considered the site and the owners were committed to a community-serving use
urges approval of the project

speaker_statements.speaker: cristy johnston
lines: asks for approval
notes the group usually does not support formula retail, but this case is different because the owner sought help, they like the model, and a community process occurred

speaker_statements.speaker: silvia johnson
lines: mentions the process may take about three weeks and is trying to find the address
states her music relates to her family history

ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, sugaya

project_descr: Mandatory Discretionary Review, under the Planning Commission's policy requiring review of dwelling unit mergers, of Building Permit Application No. 2007.07.18.7085, which proposes to merge two existing dwelling-units into one single-family home.
preliminary_recommendation: take discretionary review and disapprove the project as proposed

speaker_statements.speaker: john hude
lines: requests approval of the unit merger
notes ~25% of san francisco housing stock has 3–4 bedrooms
cites policies 1.2, 1.5, and 1.6 on affordable housing; says this unit is not affordable stock
argues the merged unit fits prevailing neighborhood density and fabric
says the unit will be owner-occupied, returning to single-family without displacing anyone, and has enthusiastic neighborhood support

speaker_statements.speaker: paul nasvik
lines: intends to keep living in the home; loves the neighborhood and is active in the community
states they are not developers and not doing this for profit
notes wendy works from home as an editor; he is in nursing school at san francisco state with a goal to work at san francisco general

action: did not take discretionary review and approved
ayes: antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2006.08.29.0915, proposing to legalize an existing deck and one-story structure at the rear of a single-family dwelling built without benefit of permit.
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretionary review and approve the proposal as submitted
speakers: hai ying mai, wendy huang, [no name stated], jose diaz, susan avila, graciela diaz

speaker_statements.speaker: hai ying mai
lines: opposes the project because it was built without a permit and without consulting neighbors
says the railing is too high and raises serious privacy concerns
questions whether the building meets standards

speaker_statements.speaker: wendy huang
lines: notes her house is 20 feet from the project and asks that the deck be removed
says the deck blocks sunlight and views and faces two of her bedrooms, affecting privacy

speaker_statements.speaker: no name
lines: states the deck was built illegally and infringes on legally protected privacy

speaker_statements.speaker: jose diaz
lines: says he tried to work with both requestors but faced a language barrier
argues the lattice improves privacy for both families
proposes bringing the deck up to code, cutting it back 3 feet from the property line and 2 feet from the front
notes the requestors did not attend the variance hearing
reports a building inspector visit found everything okay except minor repairs; says he is doing his best

speaker_statements.speaker: susan avila
lines: supports the sponsor, saying he tried—unsuccessfully—to work with requestors even after being advised to get a translator
says the deck and lattice provide privacy for both homes

speaker_statements.speaker: graciela diaz
lines: says the deck is not used often
offers to add plants to increase privacy if the project is approved

action: took discretionary review and approved requiring
requirements: removal of all lattice work except the one on the left side as you face the building from the rear
place vine plants to increase privacy
ayes: olague, antonini, s. lee, w. lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Variance request to be considered by the Zoning Administrator for rear yard, for the project proposing to legalize an existing deck and one-story structure at the rear of a single-family dwelling built without benefit of permit.
speakers: hai ying mai, wendy huang, [no name stated], jose diaz, susan avila, graciela diaz
action: zoning administrator granted the variance with the same condition imposed from the discretionary review

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2007.05.09.0766, proposing construction of a two-story, horizontal rear addition to a two-story dwelling
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretionary review and approve the project as proposed by the revised plans

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2007.08.09.9290, proposing to expand an existing Small Self-Service Restaurant (dba The Grove Cafe) into a vacant retail space to the west (formerly occupied by an extension of a retail clothing store dba Jack's). The expansion would add approximately 660 square feet and 27 seats to the existing 48-seat restaurant and would also establish the expanded restaurant as a Full Service Restaurant.
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretionary review and approve the project as proposed
speakers: charles bain, jai das, stefano cassolato, eric j. messersmith, carl hilsz, ken zankel

speaker_statements.speaker: charles bain
lines: frames issue as preserving neighborhood and commercial corridors amid loss of spaces
says extended hours would have big impacts and parking is already impossible
argues the neighborhood has reached saturation even if the business is a 'model'
urges no increase or expansion; keep it as-is

speaker_statements.speaker: jai das
lines: notes many tourists shop in the area and business has improved this year
warns expansion would heighten competition; says diversity should be maintained

speaker_statements.speaker: stefano cassolato
lines: opposes project due to existing parking and traffic problems, especially on weekends

speaker_statements.speaker: eric j. messersmith
lines: concerned about saturation of restaurants in the area

speaker_statements.speaker: carl hilsz
lines: main concern is neighborhood preservation
disputes that a 'modest' increase equals a 50% capacity bump
if approved, requests self-service rather than full-service to mitigate parking/traffic impacts

speaker_statements.speaker: ken zankel
lines: says they are not fast food and never applied as such
proposes no change in service; operations remain the same
states increase is <30% for their restaurant and <1% of total seats in the four-block area
says no tenants were displaced; the adjacent space was always vacant
reads a letter from Supervisor Pier recommending approval
submits 651 individual petitions and 13 petitions from nearby restaurants supporting the project
seeks approval largely to add a second ADA-compliant bathroom (already have one)
emphasizes doing things legally—rent, construction, insurance—and adding seats
notes local ownership, employee advancement to partnerships, and community contributions

action: did not take discretionary review and approved
